Award.AwardTitle: SMP: Professional Applied and Computational Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).
The Professional Applied and Computational Mathematics program is a collaborative Science Masters Program offered by Buffalo State College and its business partners. The program is educating graduate students for careers in emerging fields that demand a new type of workforce with solid and in-depth background in applied and computational mathematics, as well as effective business and communication skills. This program uses graduate faculty with demonstrated records to educate students in both the classroom and the workplace. This faculty has created a carefully designed and extremely thorough curriculum that includes 9-credits in each the topics of (1) data analysis, (2) mathematical modeling, and (3) business and communication skills. As part of the program students also complete a 3-credit internship. The core courses are broken into 1-credit modules, which are easy to be upgraded or replaced and include "real world" case studies. The research and internship experiences provide students opportunity to analyze and solve "real world" problems.

The broader impact of the program includes (1) increasing the participation of female students and students from under-represented minorities in graduate studies in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics disciplines and (2) preparing graduate students for careers in business, industry, non-profit organizations, and government agencies with a strong foundation in applied and computational mathematics, as well as business and communication skills, to succeed in those careers that demand a broadly inclusive, well-trained science and engineering workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Professional Applied and Computational Mathematics Program (PACM) at SUNY Buffalo State accepted its first cohort of students in Fall 2010 with the support of SMP-NSF grant 1011166. The first cohort had 4 students (1 female and two males funded by SMP-NSF, and one international student). The program is currently in its fourth cohort, has had 44 students enrolled in the program (3 have dropped, 18 have graduated, and the remaining are expected to graduate).

 

The placement of PACM graduates in jobs directly related to their internship and training thus far has been 15/18 (one of the three students not employed is the international student mentioned above from our first cohort, who is enrolled in a Ph.D. program in applied mathematics with full support; the other two are recent graduates and are exploring their best options).

The director of PACM (a professor of applied mathematics), the coordinator (an assistant professor in the math department with a Ph.D. in business Operations Management) and the steering and oversight committee (experienced faculty in the applied mathematics area) have created and implemented 23 new 1-credit courses in statistical data analysis, mathematical modeling and optimization, and three 3-credit courses in business skills tailored to math and science professionals. This was accomplished in close collaboration with members of local industry, research labs, and government agencies. Students have experienced frequent presentations from industry leaders, visits to workplaces, job interviews, social and networking events, and more. All students have completed at least one supervised internship, culminating in a formal written a report and an oral presentation and/or a poster presentation.

We have actively pursued female and under-represented minority students for the program, offering support to qualified applicants via the NSF grant, when possible. The 2010 PACM cohort was 25% (1 of 4) female and 25% were African American (1 of 4). The 2011 PACM cohort was 36% female (5 of 14) and 14% (2 of 14) minority (African American, Hispanic). The 2012 PACM cohort is 55% female (5 of 9) with 1 Latino woman. The 2013 PACM cohort is 36% female (5 out of 14).

This project has positively impacted Buffalo State and the region. In regards to Buffalo State, other programs and the math department have a number of choices that were not available before our program was created. For instance:

  1. Students from other graduate programs have taken our Project Management for Math and Science Professionals course.
  2. Math majors in our graduate program now have Math Education (existing for many years) and PACM as a choice.
  3. From our relationships with businesses, students in the sciences and mathematics will have more opportunities to learn about the use of mathematics in the real world and jobs available.
  4. From our relationship with businesses, students have been able to find internships and research projects.
  5. Several math teachers have chosen to pursue PACM as their NYS required MS degree. This will extend the spirit of integrating academia and industry further to the middle and high school.

Regionally, PACM students are required to complete an internship; and the list of internship locations reflects the range of places we interact with and the impact to the region. All internships below are in the Buffalo region:

 

Great Lakes Research Center (affiliated with Buffalo State) (2 internships)

M&T Bank (6 internships)

Independent Health (7 internships)

Hauptman-Woodward Medical Institute (1 internship)

Fisher Price (1 internship)

Roswell Park Cancer Institute (2 internships)

YMCA (1 internship)
